title: Executive Coach or Therapist? It’s Getting Harder to Tell the Difference
text:
In the middle of a family crisis, Aishetu Fatima Dozie, a Harvard Business School graduate, decided to call her executive coach. The two had grown close, and it wasn’t unusual for personal matters to come up during sessions. The conversation made her feel better, but apparently it crossed a line.

The next time they spoke, she says her coach told her, “That was a one-off. I’m not your therapist.” Ms. Dozie, who was working for a South African bank then and who has since founded a cosmetics e-commerce startup in the Bay Area, was disappointed she couldn’t have what she saw as a two-in-one counselor. “I liked it,” she said, “but she clearly thought this was not what we should be doing.”

There’s a certain appeal to having a Wendy Rhodes in your life. The psychiatrist from Showtime’s “Billions” helps hedge-fund employees crush it while also uncovering the deeper roots of their feelings, thoughts and behaviors. (Was that last deal motivated by potential gain…or by personal spite?)

In real life, coaches are especially prevalent in tech. There are various reasons for this, according to people in the industry. Starting a company can be all-consuming and isolating. Startups can grow rapidly, and founders aren’t always ready for the highs and lows and the massive workload involved.

Startup founders have shared their struggles, including mental-health issues. Andy Cook, founder of Tettra, a software startup, recently floated on Twitter the idea of venture-capital firms offering in-house therapists. He decided to see one after ending an engagement and says it helped his work life.

“In the tech industry, you have to project this aura of, I have it under control,” he says. “There’s a huge stigma around going to see a therapist and it’s almost like admitting you can’t handle your own mental state,” he says. “Maybe it’s easier for people to go see a coach because that’s more accepted.”

Share Your Thoughts Have you used an executive coach? If so, how personal do you get? Join the conversation below.

The overlap between coaching and therapy has always been there, some coaches say. But others say that in recent years, the lines are getting blurrier.

As long as coaches aren’t treating addiction, diagnosing mental-health disorders or working clients through abuse or trauma, they’re within bounds, some in the industry say. Others caution that coaching is straying too far into the territory of mental health—and that’s a problem. Not only is there a lack of regulation in coaching, the coach-client relationship isn’t a legally protected one.

Nonetheless, some people who would shun a “therapist” would gladly schedule regular visits with a “coach” due to common perceptions that therapy is only focused on processing the past and is reserved for people with mental-health issues.

Julie Gurner, an executive coach in New York City, is trained as a psychologist, though she doesn’t have a license to practice and intentionally stays away from anything that might look like therapy. She says clients tell her sometimes about issues they have been working on with previous coaches, such as cutting back on the use of certain drugs. “And I’m like, ‘That’s not an issue that person should be addressing.’”

Kara Nortman, a partner with the venture-capital firm Upfront Ventures in Los Angeles, says in her experience, it’s not uncommon for founders and others in the tech sector to use their coach as a de facto therapist.

Ms. Nortman herself worked with a coach on managing acute emotional reactions she was having in certain work situations, such as difficulty accepting feedback. She says when she has suggested to friends who work in senior tech positions to go to therapy she has met resistance, but she can usually convince them to see a coach.

“It’s sort of like a badge of honor to have a coach,” she says.

The coach-therapist hybrid has become an appealing option. Some psychologists have been adding coaching to their services in recent years, or making the switch entirely. Conversely, some coaches who don’t have formal psychological training see their work as bridging the gap between therapy and coaching.

The nonprofit International Coach Federation, has a code of ethics and put out its first-ever guidelines last year on when and how a coach should suggest a client seek help from a mental-health professional. “We frequently would hear coaches asking, ‘I don’t know when to refer someone to therapy,’” says Joel DiGirolamo, director of coaching science with the ICF.

Kelley Amadei, an executive coach who splits her time between New York and San Francisco and who has worked in human resources and corporate leadership, says the traditional, more tactical style of coaching—one that didn’t take into account the whole person—just didn’t work that well.

As an executive at Heineken, Ms. Amadei evaluated the effectiveness of the coaches, both internal and external, that the company paid for. “There was a very particular formula that was used,” she says. “Most people weren’t making significant step change in performance, in delivery, in self awareness or in behavior.”

Ms. Amadei’s current practice combines Buddhist psychology, organizational and individual psychology and discussion of business goals. She asks deeply personal questions, including about her clients’ childhoods and significant events that shaped them. People joke about her being an unlicensed therapist.

“In some ways, that’s true,” she says. “Therapy as a paradigm is broad. Coaching as a paradigm can be broad. And we’ve put them in really small boxes and decided they are separate.”

Transparency is key, she says. This means being upfront about her training and experience. She doesn’t treat addiction, diagnose mental-health disorders or work with clients on resolving trauma, or abuse. She might share general feedback with a client’s employer but won’t get into any details about sessions without a client’s permission. One company declined to hire her as a result.

Kenneth Berger, an executive coach in San Francisco, draws similar boundaries.

“I don’t know how to diagnose anxiety. I can only use anxiety in the colloquial sense,” he says. “‘What are you noticing about the way you’re thinking about this? The way you’re feeling about this?’ Then we have the opportunity to bring that in toward their vision, where they want to go, their values.”

However, his clients are welcome to talk about any aspects of their lives. “People’s lives are complex and what’s happening at home is happening at work,” he says. While he uses tools similar to those of cognitive behavioral therapy, he says he applies them differently and views his work as fundamentally distinct from therapy.

Cameron Yarbrough, a licensed therapist and founder of the coaching startup Torch, says coaching might make more people more willing to try therapy, but that a huge negative is the lack of regulations surrounding coach confidentiality.

“It’s very common for coaches to have loose lips,” says Mr. Yarbrough. “I have seen really ugly examples of executive coaches oversharing content to boards of directors, to co-founders, to unrelated parties—confidential and sensitive information.”

Lesly Higgins, an executive coach in the Bay Area, says when a client comes to her with a personal issue that’s affecting work, she asks herself, “Do I have the skills and training to be effective, and is it appropriate based on who’s hired me to do this work?”

When one client was debating leaving a company to seek an M.B.A. or pursue other opportunities, Ms. Higgins felt advising on those issues presented a potential conflict of interest as the client’s employer was paying her bill. But if a client is going through a divorce or dealing with the effects of fertility treatments, she might guide them on strategies for how to remain productive at work while experiencing those issues.

One of her clients was a senior tech executive contemplating a new, high-paying job as his company was being acquired. Through work with his therapist and Ms. Higgins, he determined his career decisions had always been based on how much money he made. That’s how his parents measured success.

“He said, ‘I realized in our work together that the very first time I made a million dollars, the first thing I did was send a copy of my W-2 to my dad,’” she says.

In the end, he decided to forgo the high-paying position to join a startup, a job with less prestige and certainty but one he thought would make him happier.

—“Keywords” columnist Christopher Mims is on book leave.
description: Having your own Wendy Rhodes can be a badge of honor, but as lines blur some see problems. A big one: no legal confidentiality protection.
